Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Small: Values of Information Technology for Progress: Three Case Studies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop methods for using historical understanding of technology to assess potential consequences of sociotechnical change and to inspire new design practices. Information technology (IT) builds on a longer history of technology tied to significant cultural shifts, commonly conceptualized as technological innovations driving societal progress. This research critically analyzes the idea of sociotechnical progress by asking: How is it conceptualized? What practices, values, and stakeholders become marginalized in the pursuit of progress, what are its consequences, and how can currently marginalized factors inspire new forms of design? It uses these questions to evaluate roles that IT has played in progress, and to envision and design for new roles it could play.

This project answers these questions through three case studies that look at societies on the global margin which have seized on technological progress as a means for bettering their circumstances. The case studies look at (1) a past attempt to rapidly transform from a subsistence, fishing-based to an industrialized economy in rural Newfoundland; (2) the consequences of a similar transformation in present Iceland, where pervasive adoption of information technology has transformed the small-boat fishing industry; and (3) debates over possible futures arising from the sudden and pervasive adoption of mobile phone technology in Jamaica. These novel case studies provide a new lens through which to understand the values embodied in information technology, its cultural impact, and their implications for practices in the field of human-computer interaction.

Methodologically, this work builds on design ethnography to demonstrate how historical methods can enrich the ability of work in human-computer interaction to address the broader cultural impacts of technology. By analyzing how the consequences of modernization compare with hopes invested in technology as a tool for progress, the project will provide evidence to support a more rigorous debate about the impact of information technologies. By using this analysis to generate new design insights, the project supports design practices that may improve the implications of technology, especially as productivity tools and means for advancing economic development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the rapid uptake of information technologies is sweeping through our society, many designers are asking how they can make positive social impacts through technology design.  This project analysed three case studies of technology adoption intended to create sociotechnical progress. It used this analysis to identify factors that influence the long-term impact of technology and to develop new methods to use design thinking to explore the current implications of technology and envision new alternatives with better impact.

Intellectual Merit: Through examination of past rapid modernization in rural Newfoundland, Canada in the 1960’s, the project identified recurring factors in technology design that inadvertently marginalize rural communities, particularly by building in assumptions about ways of working that do not match the constraints of remote places.  Through examination of the present consequences of modernization on the highly informated Icelandic small-boat fishing industry, the project uncovered how as the fishing industry is framed ever more with regards to data tracking, it has come to frame a sustainable catch as a problem of maximizing numbers in ways that are likely to undermine actual sustainability. Through examination of debates around future modernization tied to the rise of a class of mobile app entrepreneurs in Jamaica, the project identified how the assumed universality of Silicon Valley methods breaks down in places that are working under significantly different constraints and act to counteract the economic hopes that the IT industry embodies. The project developed a method to use collections of speculative designs to explore the consequences of ethnographic and historical insight for design and to further inform social science investigation of the social impacts of technology.

Broader Impact: The project developed a new upper-level undergraduate course on Designing Technology for Social Impact, which was iterated 4 times and has become one of the most popular courses in the Information Science major, with 176 students in Fall 2017. Through the design and execution of this course, the project developed teaching methods that integrate specific design methods such as peer production or persuasive design with sociological and historical analysis of the social impact of existing technologies. It used the speculative design method developed in the project to explore and ideate designs as a core component of the class. The project also collected and preserved oral histories in an endangered community and provided training and mentoring to several Jamaican start-ups in collaboration with the World Bank and Start-Up Jamaica.
